DOC.HEAD: Hate Group Monitors Say Racists Most Logical Suspects in Mail Bombs
With AM-Mail Bombs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People who track hate groups said Tuesday that white supremacists are logical suspects in the mail-bomb killings of a federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Georgia. Racist mentalities fit the bill in both motive and mode: they are angry over recent defeats in court cases, and they have a historical bent for bombings, according to two hate group watchers. ``There's no reason to disbelieve they would be connected to these incidents. They have planned to kill federal judges before, and there have been similar incidents with bombs,'' said Danny Levitan, executive director of the Center for Democratic Renewal in Atlanta. On Saturday, a mail bomb killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert S. Vance, who wrested control of the Alabama Democratic Party from white supremacists during the 1960s, at his home in a Birmingham, Ala., suburb. On Monday, another mail bomb killed Savannah, Ga., Alderman Robert Robinson, an attorney who was working on a long-running school desegregation case. A fourth bomb was found Tuesday at the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The office was evacuated and the bomb, which arrived in the mail Monday but was left unopened, was disarmed, officials said. FBI Director William Sessions told a Washington news conference Tuesday that the pattern didn't fit white supremacist groups, but said they weren't being ruled out. The FBI has warned civil rights activists as well as lawyers and judges to beware of strange packages because of the possibility white supremacists mailed the Savannah bomb. The bombs that killed Vance and Robinson were pipe bombs containing nails, authorities said. Racist groups typically use that sort of bomb, said Leonard Zeskind, research director for the Center for Democratic Renewal. ``The Klan and Nazi groups are more likely to use pipe or powder bombs,'' he said. ``Plastic (explosives) is drug stuff.'' Recent court losses have hurt racist groups in the pocketbook and in efforts to recruit more members, giving them a potential motive for retaliation, said Pat Carter of Klanwatch. ``Some of these groups are perturbed that they are losing their assets,'' she said. ``It has made their membership very bitter.'' In 1987, a U.S. District Court jury awarded $7 million to the mother of a Mobile, Ala., teen-ager murdered in 1981 by two Ku Klux Klansmen. Last year, a U.S. District Court jury in Atlanta awarded $950,400 in damages to two civil rights leaders because of violence surrounding the first of two civil rights marches in Forsyth County, Ga., in 1987. White supremacist groups have enjoyed renewed popularity in the South over the past decade. Incidents of racial hatred surged from eight in 1978 to 276 in 1986, the last year for which figures were available, according to statistics compiled by the U.S. Justice Department's Community Relations Service. The Center for Democratic Renewal, formerly the Anti-Klan Network, found 3,000 racial incidents reported between 1980 and 1986, including about 500 in 1986 alone, Levitan said. ``We view the level of hate crimes as having reached epidemic proportions,'' he said. ``Skinheads and youth are at the cutting edge.'' Skinheads favor extremely short haircuts. Many, but not all, also embrace white supremacist ideology. Klanwatch, a unit of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., has identified at least 11 active hate groups in Georgia and Alabama, including two Skinhead groups in Alabama and one in Georgia.
